job.title: Software Engineer
job.description: We are looking for a skilled software engineer to join our team.
soft_skills: Responsible for design and development of high end, robust, scalable products that disrupt the market
Technically-intense role with primary focus on building cool products in a niche domain

messages.content: Hi Sai Varun! Great to meet you - I'm really excited to chat about the software engineer position and learn more about your background. I hope you're having a good day so far, and thanks for taking the time to connect with us at TechCorp.

Hi Sai Varun! Great to meet you - I'm really excited to chat about the software engineer position and learn more about your background. I hope you're having a good day so far, and thanks for taking the time to connect with us at TechCorp.

Looking at your chat-room project where you used Web Sockets and Node.js, let's say you needed to add a feature where users can send emoji reactions to messages. You have a message object like this: `{id: 123, content: 'Hello everyone!', reactions: []}`. Can you write a JavaScript function that takes a message object, an emoji string, and a user ID, and adds the reaction to the message? If the same user tries to add the same emoji again, it should remove their previous reaction instead.

Good solution! Now what if multiple users could react with the same emoji to the same message? How would you modify your function to handle a structure where reactions are grouped by emoji, like `{reactions: {'üëç': ['user1', 'user2'], '‚ù§Ô∏è': ['user3']}}`?

Looking at your chat-room project, let's switch to Python for a moment. You'd likely need to validate user messages before broadcasting them. Write a Python function that takes a message string and returns True if it's valid (between 1-500 characters, contains at least one non-whitespace character, and doesn't contain any HTML tags like
I‚Äôll implement this in a clean, practical way, similar to what I‚Äôd actually use in a backend service before broadcasting messages.

For your Chat-room project, you mentioned using MongoDB, but let's say you need to add SQL analytics to track message statistics. Write a SQL query to find the top 3 most active users (by message count) in each chat room, assuming you have tables: `users(id, username)`, `rooms(id, room_name)`, and `messages(id, user_id, room_id, content, created_at)`. Show the room name, username, and message count.

For your Chat-room project, you mentioned using MongoDB, but let's say you need to add SQL analytics to track message statistics. Write a SQL query to find the top 3 most active users (by message count) in each chat room, assuming you have tables: `users(id, username)`, `rooms(id, room_name)`, and `messages(id, user_id, room_id, content, created_at)`. Show the room name, username, and message count.

Thank you, Sai Varun, for taking the time to discuss your experience with JavaScript, Python, and SQL today - your responses demonstrated solid technical understanding across these key areas for the Software Engineer role. That concludes our interview, and I'll now be generating a comprehensive report based on our conversation covering all 4 questions we discussed. You should expect to hear about next steps from our team within the coming days, and I appreciate your interest in joining our organization.

evaluations.notes: Clean, correct implementation with proper toggle logic and good naming conventions
